b'b\' Here is my first contribution to add subtitles support to Sick-Beard using [my own fork of periscope]url Configuration page with CSS
column11: icons and jsSubtitles download at post-process timeDownload subtitles button in the show pageSubtitles download in "Manage" page for mass editingSubtitles download on a regular basis on its own thread (or not? not sure yet) You can choose to bring periscope into Sick-Beard
column12: like other libraries. But I think I\\\'m gonna make some more changes in periscope-ng.## Steps to install periscope-ng:### Warning: If you have periscope installed (the original project)
column13: this will interfere and replace it with my version.Periscope-ng requires python module BeautifulSoup >= 3.2.0. If you are a Ubuntu Natty user
column14: you can install it with your Synaptic.### Steps:1.  2.  3.  \''

column10: b"b' Great work but why not add Periscope-ng to the lib folder
column11: this would aviod any interference with users that already have periscope installed.'"

column10: b'b\' Because I leave the choice of implementation up to midgetspy. I think that putting periscope-ng as a lib is a good idea too.Periscope-ng works on it\\\'s own as a module and I want to keep it\\\'s development separated from Sick-Beard\\\'s development until I release a final stable version of periscope-ng. Edit: Missclicked on "Comment and close" -_-\''
b'b" I think this is an amazing idea
column11: as I\'m guessing it will tie the subtitles to the file on download? Meaning that once you have the files downloaded and renamed you don\'t have to guess what subtitle version to get?"'

column10: b'b" Actually
column11: it attempts to download subtitles at post processing.Anyway
column12: it is possible that no subtitles are found so I made possible to re-launch it in the show page and mass edit page (manage menu).Depending on plugins used
column13: periscope can use :A hash of the video file (OpenSubtitles
column14: TheSubDB)Guessed data from filename (for web-scrapping plugins and some others) The last point can be improved and I\'m working on using a robust library for filenames parsing as Patrick Dessales for -ng."'

column10: b"b' Added JSON fallback functions for XBMC
column11: in case HTTP API fails or is non...'"

column10: b'b" ...-existent This is a new set of functions in the XBMC notification code for using the XBMC JSON API to do communications.  Recently
column11: XBMC has pulled out the HTTP API in their development code
column12: so anyone running  builds of XBMC hasn\'t been able to get SickBeard to automatically update libraries. The code is written so that it will try the HTTP API first
column13: then go to JSON if the HTTP API fails.  This way
column14: people that aren\'t on XBMC nightlies will continue to use the same code they always have. There was one tweak I made that affected the HTTP API code... The XBMC Test Notification code didn\'t return a  like the rest of the notiifiers; it returned the http that came back
column15: and then the calling code parsed it out.  I just moved the parsing of the return string into the notifier code so it could return
column16: and updated  to expect a  out of it. In doing all this
column17: I did find a bug in the development code of XBMC that actually makes this somewhat useless at the moment... url  which led to url  ... Until they get this bug resolved
column18: you still need to run the auto-clean.  Oh well
column19: not much I can do about that. All I can say is that the JSON code works on the ubuntu nightly ppa XBMC.  Anything else probably shouldn\'t matter
column20: due to JSON being used only if HTTP API fails."'

column10: b'b" I see someone beat me to the punch and is working with Zoggy... I\'ll leave this here
column11: just in case.  Otherwise

column10: b'b" thanks for the submission
column11: slightly different approach than the branching code tactic wsnipez used. i\'ve found issues in his code and will spend some time tonight rewriting things.. i\'ll reference your submission as well."'

column10: b'b\' FYI
column11: there are a couple of annoyances in my code.. Those of us on bleeding edge (ie
column12: we need the JSON interface) get double hits to XBMC (first hit for HTTP API
column14: then the JSON calls).  On a local network
column17: but it does show up in the XBMC debug logs as a hit to the http server.  I always pictured that once the official release of XBMC goes out with the HTTP API pulled
column18: the order of functions would get reversed so that JSON is attempted first
column20: the HTTP functions would get removed entirely. Due to that double hit
column21: some extra logging happens in SickBeard due to the HTTP API library update function throwing off a  message in the event of a failure.  It\\\'s something I had meant to refactor a little bit (moving the Error logging up to the externally called function)

b"b' Adding option to order by DVD ordering'"

b'b\' This is an important option for TV Shows to allow for returning the results in DVD order instead of Airdate Order. Why is this important? Because many people are ripping their TV shows and using SickBeard to manage them and automatically name and process them. The change here allows you to add shows like "Batman: The Animated Series" and "Firefly" where the network screwed up the air ordering but fixed it in a subsequent DVD release. This PR requires a library update: url \''

column10: b'b" @thezoggy that makes sense. Thank you. I tried running the existing test suite and I got two failures and an error. I tried again in master but it seems the tests are broken at the moment. If I had my way
column11: I would use HTTPretty url  to test this change with an integration test. That would add quite a bit of coverage for existing Sick-Beard code because it would use all the existing code and only override the call to thetvdb at the socket level. It would still be quick and deterministic since we would be defining the return value for the call and it wouldn\'t actually use the network. I\'ve done similar tests at my job and I am currently working on a test suite for the Paython library that uses this method. The only reason I didn\'t go crazy and write that test was because I wasn\'t sure if my PR would be rejected for doing so and I didn\'t want to do all that work for nothing. If you gave me the go-ahead
column12: I would work on an integration test suite for the tvdb calls in Sick-Beard using HTTPretty. I\'d also be happy to take a crack at fixing the existing tests so that we could set up some CI for this awesome project. Let me know what you think. Thanks!"'
